data.title: MiMedx Group (MDXG) Revenue Jump To US$118.1 Million Tests Slow Growth Narrative
data.description:
MiMedx Group (MDXG) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of about US$118.1 million and basic EPS of roughly US$0.10, while trailing twelve month figures sit at around US$418.6 million of revenue and US$0.33 of basic EPS. Over the past few quarters, the company has seen revenue move from US$84.1 million in Q3 2024 to US$92.9 million in Q4 2024 and then to US$118.1 million in Q4 2025, with quarterly basic EPS ranging from about US$0.05 to US$0.11 across that stretch. With a trailing net profit margin of 11.6%, the latest earnings print gives investors a clear view of a business that is currently generating consistent profits.

See our full analysis for MiMedx Group.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings story lines up against the widely followed narratives around MiMedx's growth, profitability, and longer term potential.

See what the community is saying about MiMedx Group

Advertisement

TTM profit of US$48.6 million supports 11.6% margin story

  • Over the last twelve months to Q4 2025, MiMedx generated about US$418.6 million of revenue and US$48.6 million of net income, which lines up with the 11.6% net margin mentioned earlier and shows profit has stayed in the low double digits.
  • Analysts' consensus view links this kind of profitability to long term earnings potential, yet the small move in net margin from about 12% to 11.6% shows that while the business is currently earning solid profits, it is not breaking away from margin pressure as clearly as the consensus narrative suggests.

Quarterly EPS range of US$0.05 to US$0.11 keeps growth grounded

  • Across the last six reported quarters, basic EPS has sat in a fairly tight band between roughly US$0.05 and US$0.11 per share, with Q4 2025 at about US$0.10 and trailing twelve month EPS at about US$0.33, which shows earnings are positive but not moving in a straight line.
  • Supporters in the bullish camp point to strong clinical positioning and product expansion as drivers of long term earnings, yet the step up and down in quarterly EPS within this US$0.05 to US$0.11 range reminds you that even with those tailwinds, the earnings path has been bumpy rather than smooth so far.
    • The bullish narrative highlights diversified product expansion and operational efficiencies as reasons to expect stronger earnings over time, while the actual EPS path from about US$0.05 in Q1 2025 to roughly US$0.11 in Q3 2025 and US$0.10 in Q4 2025 shows that cost and revenue timing still matter a lot quarter to quarter.
    • Backers also argue that investments in clinical trials and new launches can support margin improvement, but with trailing twelve month net income of around US$48.6 million on US$418.6 million of revenue, the current earnings base is still modest compared with the growth ambitions in that bullish story.

Bulls argue there is more to this EPS trend than the last few quarters show, and if you want to see how they frame the upside case in detail you can check out üêÇ MiMedx Group Bull Case

P/E of 15.1x vs slower 3.8% revenue forecast

  • MiMedx is reported on a trailing P/E of 15.1x compared with a DCF fair value of US$14.55 per share and a current share price of US$4.94, while revenue growth is projected at about 3.8% per year, which is slower than the 10.4% figure cited for the broader US market.
  • Critics in the bearish narrative focus on reimbursement changes and a concentrated product set as reasons that growth could be pressured, and the combination of a 3.8% revenue growth forecast and a net margin close to 11.6% gives those worries some footing even though the current P/E is lower than the 23x industry average.
    • The bearish view highlights potential Medicare reforms and possible market contraction as threats to both volumes and margins, and the already slower projected top line growth compared with the broader market shows why those policy shifts matter for future revenue lines.
    • Concerns about reliance on a limited placental allograft portfolio also tie back to the 11.6% net margin, because if reimbursement or competing products affect that core segment, the current earnings level of roughly US$48.6 million on US$418.6 million of sales could be sensitive to any shock in that main business.

Skeptics watching that 15.1x P/E against slower projected growth may want to see how a more cautious case is laid out in full through üêª MiMedx Group Bear Case

data.title: BlueNord (OB:BNOR) Q4 Profitability Surge Tests Bearish Earnings Decline Narrative
data.description:
BlueNord (OB:BNOR) closed out FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$362 million and basic EPS of US$2.21, while trailing 12 month figures showed revenue of US$1.04 billion and EPS of US$3.74. Over the past few quarters, revenue has moved from US$192.9 million in Q4 2024 to US$171.1 million in Q1 2025, US$260.2 million in Q2, US$246 million in Q3, and then US$362 million in Q4, with quarterly EPS shifting from a loss of US$2.86 to profits between US$0.19 and US$2.21. With the company now profitable on a trailing basis, the latest numbers put the focus on how durable those margins look against softer forward forecasts and financing risks.

See our full analysis for BlueNord.

With the headline figures on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings profile lines up with the key narratives around BlueNord, and where the numbers start to challenge those stories.

See what the community is saying about BlueNord

Advertisement

TTM profit of US$97.5 million changes the story

  • On a trailing basis BlueNord earned US$97.5 million of net income and US$3.74 in EPS on US$1.04b of revenue, compared with a trailing loss of US$70.8 million a year earlier on US$702.3 million of revenue.
  • Bulls highlight that this move into profitability, alongside reported 5 year earnings growth of 14.5% per year, fits their view that Tyra ramp up and lower lifting costs can support long duration cash generation, although forecasts of roughly 2.5% annual earnings declines over the next three years pull in the opposite direction.

Q4 margin jump vs weaker forward forecasts

  • In Q4 2025 BlueNord generated US$55.3 million of net income on US$362 million of revenue, after earlier 2025 quarters with net income between US$4.9 million and US$18.6 million on revenue between US$171.1 million and US$260.2 million, while forecasts point to about 2.5% annual earnings declines and 0.4% annual revenue declines over the next three years.
  • Bears argue that expected revenue growth of 6.7% per year and margins rising to 8% in their narrative still sit against these softer aggregate forecasts and the company‚Äôs flagged issue that interest payments are not well covered by earnings, so they focus on the risk that periods like Q4 are hard to repeat consistently when production bottlenecks or higher operating costs show up.

Bears warn that if you are relying on strong quarters like Q4 to continue while forecasts and interest coverage look tougher, it is worth reading the full cautious case in üêª BlueNord Bear Case

P/E of 13.3x and a huge DCF gap

  • With the shares at NOK502 and trailing EPS at US$3.74, the data shows a P/E of 13.3x versus a European Oil & Gas average of 15.4x. A DCF fair value of NOK4,205.12 is very large compared with the current price and also sits well above the single analyst target level of NOK567.60 in the dataset.
  • Supporters of the bullish view point to that gap to the DCF fair value and to the idea of revenue growing 13.3% per year with margins improving to 17.8%. The same dataset flags that earnings are forecast to decline about 2.5% per year instead, so the current 13.3x multiple and weaker interest coverage give you a useful check on how much of the optimistic scenario is already being tested by actual reported numbers.

Bulls argue the current P/E and the wide gap to DCF fair value leave room if Tyra volumes and margins play out closer to their script, so if you want to see how they justify that stance, have a look at üêÇ BlueNord Bull Case

data.title: Evaluating Pan American Silver‚Äôs Valuation After Record 2025 Results And A Higher Dividend
data.description:
Advertisement

Record 2025 results and higher dividend draw investor focus

Pan American Silver (TSX:PAAS) has come into focus after reporting record fourth quarter and full year 2025 results, alongside a higher dividend and a 2026 outlook calling for further silver production growth.

For the fourth quarter, the company reported sales of US$1,179 million, compared with US$815 million a year earlier, and net income of US$452 million, compared with US$108 million. Basic and diluted earnings per share from continuing operations were US$1.07, compared with US$0.30 a year ago.

Across 2025, sales were US$3.62b compared with US$2.82b a year earlier, while net income was US$978 million compared with US$112 million. Full year basic and diluted earnings per share from continuing operations were US$2.56, compared with US$0.31 in the prior year.

Alongside the earnings release on February 18, 2026, Pan American Silver declared a cash dividend of US$0.18 per common share for the fourth quarter of 2025, payable on or about March 13, 2026, to shareholders of record as of March 2, 2026. The company described the dividend as an eligible dividend for Canadian income tax purposes and noted that any future dividends will remain at the discretion of its board.

The company also updated the market on its share repurchase activity. From October 1, 2025 to December 31, 2025, Pan American Silver bought back 282,700 shares for US$15 million, representing 0.07% of its shares. This completed a program initiated on March 3, 2025, under which the company repurchased a total of 1,650,770 shares for US$46.1 million, representing 0.44% of its outstanding shares.

Management has guided to a further 14% increase in silver production in 2026, supported by contributions from the Juanicipio mine and higher grades at Cerro Moro, and plans to release an updated technical report for the La Colorada Skarn project in the second quarter of 2026. These elements sit alongside record 2025 free cash flow and a series of recent dividend increases and form the backdrop for how investors may weigh Pan American Silver‚Äôs current valuation and risk profile.

See our latest analysis for Pan American Silver.

Investors appear to be responding to the record 2025 results and higher dividend. The share price is at CA$92.37 with a 90 day share price return of 45.83%, while the 1 year total shareholder return of 171.88% and 3 year total shareholder return of roughly 4.7x point to strong longer term momentum.

If this earnings driven move has you rethinking precious metals exposure, it could be worth scanning beyond a single name and checking out our list of 7 top silver producer stocks as potential next ideas.

With the shares up 46% in 90 days and trading slightly above the average analyst price target, yet still showing a large intrinsic value gap, is there still a buying opportunity here, or is the market already pricing in future growth?

Price-to-Earnings of 29.1x: Is it justified?

On earnings, the market is putting a 29.1x P/E on Pan American Silver at CA$92.37. This sits above both peers and the company‚Äôs own estimated fair ratio.

The P/E multiple simply tells you how much investors are currently paying for each dollar of earnings. It is a common yardstick for metals and mining companies where profitability matters as much as production volumes.

For Pan American Silver, that 29.1x P/E compares with a peer average of 26.4x and an estimated fair P/E of 26.4x. This indicates the market is applying a richer tag than both the sector and the level our fair ratio suggests the price could lean toward over time.

Stacked against the broader Canadian Metals and Mining industry, where the average P/E is 22.5x, Pan American Silver‚Äôs 29.1x stands out as clearly higher. This signals that investors are currently pricing in stronger earnings prospects or a higher quality profile than the typical name in the group.

However, you are paying that richer P/E in a sector exposed to metal price swings, as well as Pan American Silver‚Äôs multi country operating and regulatory risks.

Another view on value: SWS DCF points the other way

The P/E of 29.1x suggests Pan American Silver looks expensive, but our DCF model tells a different story. At CA$92.37, the shares trade about 57.6% below our estimate of fair value at CA$217.63.   • What stands out for the bearish narrative is that this 12 month loss comes after multiple loss making quarters, including Q3 2025 net loss of C$414.0 million and Q2 2025 net loss of C$64.1 million. Critics argue this keeps cash flow and long term earnings visibility under pressure even as individual quarters like Q4 look strong.
    • Bears also point to weak coverage of interest costs and dividends, with earnings currently not covering a 3.32% dividend yield or interest expense. This ties directly into concerns about elevated debt and C$9b already spent plus C$6b still expected on Baltic Power and Hai Long.
    • At the same time, consensus commentary about step changes in EBITDA from new offshore wind and storage projects is hard to reconcile with the recent pattern of trailing losses, including a trailing loss of C$285.9 million just one quarter earlier in Q3 2025.
Northland‚Äôs recent loss pattern and debt funded build out give cautious investors plenty to question in the more optimistic forecasts of future earnings power. üêª Northland Power Bear Case

Slow 1.7% revenue growth versus wider market

  • Over the past 12 months, revenue has grown by about 1.7% per year compared to a 6.1% per year forecast for the Canadian market, even though quarterly revenue moved from C$582.3 million in Q4 2024 to C$725.3 million in Q4 2025.
  • Analysts' bullish case leans heavily on new projects like Hai Long and Baltic Power and on grid scale storage, arguing that these additions can lift margins from about 2.3% loss making levels today toward 16.5% over three years. However, the current modest 1.7% revenue growth rate and history of wind resource issues and curtailments in places like the German offshore assets show how sensitive actual revenue can be to weather and power price conditions.
    • On the supportive side for bulls, Q4 2025 revenue of C$725.3 million and net income of C$249.5 million follow Q4 2024 revenue of C$582.3 million and net income of C$126.8 million, which aligns with the view that new assets and better contract mix can improve earnings in stronger periods.
    • Against that, the same 12 month data set still shows the business unprofitable and dropping several onshore and battery projects in Ontario, Alberta, and New York. This pushes back on the idea that growth from here is straightforward or that all pipeline projects will translate into higher revenue.
For investors weighing that slower 1.7% revenue growth against the big project pipeline, it helps to see how others frame the trade off between new capacity, weather risk, and contract quality. üêÇ Northland Power Bull Case

Valuation sits below both DCF fair value and peers

  • At a current share price of C$21.69, Northland Power trades below the DCF fair value of about C$23.78 and at a P/S of 2.3x, compared with 3.0x for the broader North American renewable energy industry and 3.5x for peers.
  • Consensus narrative suggests that expansion into grid scale storage and offshore wind and the use of long term, inflation linked contracts could justify these lower multiples over time. Yet the combination of a trailing loss of C$163.2 million and interest expenses that are not well covered by earnings means the current discount can also be read as the market pricing in balance sheet risk and a reliance on analyst forecasts that expect earnings of C$454.1 million by around 2028.
    • The spread between the share price of C$21.69 and DCF fair value of C$23.78, plus a forecast earnings growth rate of about 40% per year and an analyst target of C$22.42, are the main numbers backing the view that the shares are not expensive

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a company might be worth by projecting its future cash flows and then discounting those back to today to get a single present value figure.

data.title: Simmons First National (SFNC) Net Interest Margin Rebound Tests Bearish Profitability Narratives
data.description:
Simmons First National (SFNC) closed out FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$233.9 million and basic EPS of US$0.54, following a turbulent year in which trailing twelve month figures show revenue of US$37.4 million and a basic EPS loss of US$2.96. Basic EPS shifted from US$0.20 in Q3 2024 to US$0.38 in Q4 2024, then US$0.26, US$0.43, a loss of US$4.01 and back to US$0.54 in Q4 2025. With trailing results still showing an annual loss and earlier quarters marked by compressed profitability, the latest print puts the focus firmly on whether margins can stabilise from here.

data.title: UPS Restructuring Shifts From Amazon To Higher Margin Growth And Valuation
data.description:
• UPS (NYSE:UPS) is closing 22 union staffed sortation centers this year, as part of a plan that could shutter up to 200 facilities by 2030.
  • The company is launching a voluntary buyout program for up to 105,000 drivers, targeting about 30,000 job reductions.
  • The restructuring is tied to a pivot away from lower margin Amazon deliveries and toward areas such as healthcare logistics and automation.

UPS, a global parcel delivery and logistics provider, is reshaping how its network is set up as e commerce and business shipping patterns evolve. The company is moving away from a heavy reliance on Amazon volumes and is putting more focus on higher margin categories like healthcare shipments and automated facilities. For investors, the changes highlight how management is rethinking where and how UPS earns its money.

Looking ahead, the closures and driver buyout program could meaningfully alter UPS cost base and operational footprint by 2030. The key questions for shareholders will be how effectively UPS reallocates capacity to targeted growth areas and how the restructuring affects service quality, labor relations, and long term profitability.

data.title: California Water Service Group (CWT) Margin Compression Tests Bullish Earnings Narrative
data.description:
California Water Service Group (CWT) has just wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$220 million and basic EPS of US$0.19, alongside net income of US$11.5 million. The company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$222 million and EPS of US$0.33 in Q4 2024 to US$220 million and EPS of US$0.19 in Q4 2025. On a trailing 12 month basis, EPS was US$2.15 on revenue of about US$1.0 billion and net income of US$128.2 million, setting up a story where investors are weighing earnings growth forecasts against a thinner profit margin profile.

See our full analysis for California Water Service Group.

Margins Under Pressure At 12.8%

  • On a trailing 12 month basis, CWT earned US$128.2 million of net income on about US$1.0b of revenue. This works out to a 12.8% net margin compared with 18.4% the prior year.
  • Analysts' consensus view is that long term earnings resilience will come from regulated rate relief and capital investment, and the current 12.8% margin puts extra focus on whether future rate decisions and PFAS cost recovery are enough to support that thesis.
    • The consensus narrative points to expanding infrastructure and reuse projects as supporting future earnings stability. The drop from 18.4% to 12.8% shows how higher compliance and treatment costs can tighten margins in the meantime.
    • With trailing 12 month net income at US$128.2 million versus US$190.8 million a year earlier, the story now hinges on whether future rate cases and cost recoveries can line up more closely with this higher investment and operating spend.

Bulls argue these margin pressures are temporary and tied to the timing of rate relief and PFAS recovery, not the earning power of the system over a full cycle. üêÇ California Water Service Group Bull Case

P/E Sits Between Industry Benchmarks

  • CWT currently trades on a 20.7x P/E, above the Global Water Utilities average of 16.8x but below the closer Water Utilities peer average of 24.8x.
  • Bears focus on this mid range P/E together with weaker coverage ratios, arguing that paying more than the global sector average looks demanding while interest and dividends are not well covered.
    • Consensus data indicates that interest payments are not well covered by earnings and that the 3.01% dividend yield is not well covered by free cash flow, which makes a 20.7x multiple look less comfortable for cautious investors.
    • At the same time, five year earnings growth of 9.1% per year and forecast growth of about 9.6% per year show why some investors still accept a P/E above the global average, even with these balance sheet pressures.

Skeptics highlight that paying 20.7x earnings while interest and dividend coverage stay tight could leave less room for error if growth or regulation disappoint. üêª California Water Service Group Bear Case

DCF Fair Value Trails Share Price

  • The DCF fair value of US$39.61 sits below the current share price of US$44.59, while the consensus analyst target of US$52.00 is above where the stock trades today.
  • What stands out in the consensus narrative is the gap between these valuation markers and the operational backdrop, where forecast earnings growth of about 9.6% per year and revenue growth of roughly 5.3% per year are being weighed against regulatory and PFAS related cost risks.
    • The analyst target of US$52.00 assumes earnings rising from about US$135.8 million today to US$187.9 million by around 2028, so any delay in rate cases or higher than expected PFAS capex would matter a lot for whether that path is achieved.
    • At the same time, forecasts for revenue to reach around US$1.1b by 2028 from roughly US$1.0b on a trailing 12 month basis illustrate how much of the valuation debate comes down to modest top line growth supporting higher margins and returns over time.

data.title: NEXTDC H1 2026 Loss Of A$57.2 Million Tests Bullish Growth Narratives
data.description:
Data center operator NEXTDC (ASX:NXT) has posted its H1 2026 scorecard with trailing 12 month revenue of A$430.26 million and a loss per share of A$0.089, keeping the company in loss-making territory. The company has seen revenue move from A$195.22 million in H2 2024 to A$205.52 million in H1 2025 and A$221.69 million in H2 2025, while half year EPS tracked at losses of A$0.041, A$0.069 and A$0.028 over the same periods. Trailing Losses Still Meaningful At A$57.2 Million

  • On a trailing 12 month view to H1 2026, NEXTDC booked a net loss of A$57.2 million on A$430.3 million in revenue, with basic EPS at a loss of A$0.089 per share.
  • Bears highlight that losses have grown at about 30.5% per year over the past five years, and this trailing 12 month loss sits in that context, while:
    • Net income on a trailing basis was A$60.5 million in loss at H2 2025 and A$65.3 million in loss at H1 2025, so the current A$57.2 million loss still reflects a business that is not covering its costs.
    • Half year figures also show losses each period, with A$17.9 million loss in H2 2025, A$42.7 million loss in H1 2025 and A$22.6 million loss in H2 2024, which supports the bearish focus on persistent negative earnings.

High Revenue Growth Forecast Versus Ongoing Unprofitability

    • Recent half year revenue has moved from A$195.2 million in H2 2024 to A$205.5 million in H1 2025 and A$221.7 million in H2 2025, so the top line has been stepping up while net income for those halves remained in loss between A$17.9 million and A$42.7 million.
    • On a trailing 12 month basis, revenue rose from A$400.7 million at H1 2025 to A$430.3 million at H1 2026, but basic EPS stayed in loss between A$0.089 and A$0.112 per share, which challenges any bullish assumption that revenue growth alone is quickly translating into profitability.

data.title: Geron (GERN) Q4 Loss Of US$31.1 Million Tests Bullish Profitability Narrative
data.description:
Geron (GERN) has just posted its FY 2025 results, with Q4 total revenue of US$48.0 million and a basic EPS loss of US$0.05, alongside trailing twelve month revenue of US$183.9 million and a TTM basic EPS loss of US$0.13. Over recent periods the company has seen quarterly revenue move between US$39.6 million and US$49.0 million, while basic EPS losses have ranged from US$0.02 to US$0.05 per quarter. This sets the backdrop for how investors assess the current TTM net loss of US$85.8 million and the pressure this puts on margins.

See our full analysis for Geron.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to line these results up against the main stories around Geron and see where the financials support those narratives and where they start to push back.

See what the community is saying about Geron

Advertisement

Losses stay wide at US$85.8 million TTM

  • Over the last twelve months, Geron booked a net loss of US$85.8 million on US$183.9 million of revenue, with quarterly net losses in FY 2025 ranging from US$16.4 million in Q2 to US$31.1 million in Q4.
  • Consensus narrative points to a path toward higher margins, but the current loss base is still sizeable:
    • Analysts see revenue growing about 56.2% per year with margins moving from a loss of 53.5% today to a 27.9% margin in around three years, while the latest TTM figures still show meaningful losses on US$183.9 million of revenue.
    • This creates a gap between the balanced view that Geron can support positive earnings in future and the current picture, where every one of the last six reported quarters, including Q4 FY 2025, shows a net loss of at least US$16.4 million.

P/S of 5.8x vs industry 12.5x

  • Geron is currently trading on a P/S of 5.8x, compared with 12.5x for the wider US biotech group and 6.9x for its peer set, while the shares trade at US$1.67 versus a DCF fair value input of about US$19.01.
  • Bulls highlight this valuation gap as a key part of their case, but the earnings profile gives important context:
    • Bullish expectations look for revenue growth of 65.9% per year and earnings of US$379.0 million by around 2028, yet the latest TTM net loss is US$85.8 million, so the step change from today‚Äôs loss-making base is large.
    • At the same time, the current 5.8x P/S and the difference between the US$1.67 share price and the US$19.01 DCF fair value input heavily support the bullish argument that the market is pricing Geron well below those optimistic growth and margin assumptions.
If you want to see how optimistic investors are connecting these numbers to a long term story, check out the detailed bull case for Geron: üêÇ Geron Bull Case

Five year loss trend vs 62.6% earnings growth forecast

  • Over the past five years, losses have widened at about 6.3% per year, and on the latest data Geron remains unprofitable, while forward-looking models point to earnings growth of about 62.6% per year and an expectation of profitability within roughly three years.
  • Bears focus on this track record as a counter to the growth story:
    • Skeptical views stress that recent history still shows a sequence of quarterly net losses, including US$31.1 million in Q4 FY 2025 and US$85.8 million over the latest twelve months, which they see as evidence that scaling revenue has not yet translated into positive earnings.
    • Against that, the forecast path to profitability within three years and the projected 62.6% annual earnings growth directly challenge the bearish concern that losses will simply continue on the same 6.3% five year trend without improving.
Skeptical about that improvement story? You can walk through the numbers behind the cautious view in more detail here: üêª Geron Bear Case
